body: I live in Japan and have well more than 35 years of experience as a pescatarian here. I have decades of experience in long-drawn out conversations in Japanese in restaurants and in other settings abou
summary: For pescatarians in Japan, communication with restaurant staff is crucial to ensure dietary needs are met.

body: I’m a native and haven’t had any issues helping traveler friends at restaurants around Japan.  I mean sure, it can be limiting depending on the menu/restaurant but that’s the same anywhere.
summary: Dining out in Japan may have limitations depending on the restaurant's menu, similar to other locations.

body: I am glad you have not had many troubles. I have had enough to always keep me alert and thorough when talking with food servers.
summary: It is important to communicate clearly with food servers to avoid dietary issues.

What time do you arrive ?

That's very, very, very overpacked. You'll be dead tired, quickly. Cut by half, leave a bit of slack, and visit an additional spot if you have time.

Day 1, you won't have e
summary: An overpacked itinerary can lead to fatigue; consider reducing activities by half for a more relaxed schedule.

body:
if you MUST pick one of these, pick #3 (and dont skip the garden at heian jingu, its the only reason to go there)

if there are sakura flowers, #2 may sound great, but #3 still is the better choice AN
summary: Heian Shrine in Kyoto is recommended for its garden, especially during the cherry blossom season.

body: If cherry blossoms are out then Higashiyama and Philosophers Path. Start early to avoid the worst of crowds. Alao Heian-jingu has cherry blossoms
summary: Visiting Higashiyama and the Philosopher's Path in Kyoto during cherry blossom season is advised; start early to avoid crowds.

body: If you do #3, the Philosopher’s path is quite close.
summary: The Philosopher's Path is conveniently located near other attractions in Kyoto.

body:
I think option 3 is probably the best, but I am very partial to Nanzen-ji. If you have any spare time you can always take a wander up the Philosopher's Path afterwards. I love that part of Kyoto.

If
summary: Nanzen-ji and the Philosopher's Path in Kyoto are highly recommended, with the possibility to explore additional nearby spots if time allows.

body: Honestly heian-jingu gardens are awesome regardless, and much easier to get to.
summary: Heian Shrine's gardens in Kyoto are highly praised and easily accessible.

body: Yeahhhhh, and it's not too far to Nanzen-ji and Keage Incline which are famous cherry blossom spots. At least at Nanzen-ji there's also a lot of space, and many trees so crowds disperse a bit
summary: Nanzen-ji and Keage Incline in Kyoto are notable for cherry blossoms and offer spacious areas that help disperse crowds.

body: Yeah Nanzenji is huge. When we were there there was a convention of some sorts and it was still incredibly easy to navigate.
summary: Nanzen-ji in Kyoto is spacious enough to navigate easily, even during events.
